page.title: 14LANDSCAPE.
page.content: This area is low-lying, crossed by the River Wey with its water meadows, and includes woods,commonland and farmland (The RHS Garden at Wisley forms a Special Feature). Marshland has kept Wisley undeveloped. Ripley and Ockham were underdeveloped as formerly owners refused to sell land and more recently because of Green Belt policies. Pyrford, originating from a river ford is a straggle of farms and more recent development, with no natural centre. Ockham was once a farming community but is now becoming residential.Ripley was built along the Portsmouth Rd, but is now by-passed by a new road built through Wisley resulting in the loss of common land and part of its ancient pool. The soil is mostly sandy with some clay. Trees are mainly oak and silver birch. Ripley's large village green has an avenue of limes.
